fr_reason: The first patent aims to improve energy production efficiency in molten carbonate fuel cells, while the second patent focuses on reducing carbon dioxide emissions in hydrocarbon cracking systems.
fr_ours: Improves energy production efficiency in molten carbonate fuel cells by adjusting hydrogen utilization beyond traditional 70% to 75%.
fr_competitor: Reduces carbon dioxide emissions in hydrocarbon cracking systems by converting methane into electricity and utilizing it in various applications.
tu_reason: The first patent recycles excess hydrogen from the anode exhaust, increasing utilization range beyond 70% to 75%, whereas the second patent converts methane into electricity using a fuel cell.
tu_ours: Recycles excess hydrogen from anode exhaust back to the anode inlet, increasing utilization range to over 10% to 30%.
tu_competitor: Uses a fuel cell to convert hydrogen-rich methane from cracking processes into electricity, thereby managing excess COâ‚‚ emissions.
sv_reason: The first patent enables more efficient energy production and potential cost reduction, whereas the second patent contributes to regulatory compliance by reducing carbon footprint.
sv_ours: Enables more efficient energy production and potential cost reduction through improved hydrogen utilization.
sv_competitor: Contributes to regulatory compliance by reducing carbon footprint and offers market applicability in industries reliant on hydrocarbon cracking systems
overall_reason: Both patents offer unique solutions for improving efficiency and reducing emissions in their respective domains.

fr_competitor: Captures CO2 from H2-rich gas mixtures, improving hydrogen purity and reducing emissions

overall_reason: Both patents showcase unique technologies with significant strategic value, but their specific focuses differ.

fr_reason: The US10252243B2 addresses the issue of high costs and energy penalties in CO2 capture processes, whereas the US9257711B2 focuses on improving energy production efficiency in molten carbonate fuel cells.
fr_ours: Improves energy production efficiency in molten carbonate fuel cells by adjusting hydrogen utilization beyond traditional 70% to 75%.
fr_competitor: Addresses high costs and energy penalties in current CO2 capture processes for power generation by utilizing an oxygen carrier in a chemical looping combustion process, preventing direct fuel-air contact and enabling exhaust gas stream consisting of CO2 and H2O only.
tu_reason: The US10252243B2 uses an oxygen carrier material to transport oxygen between air and fuel, whereas the US9257711B2 recycles excess hydrogen from the anode exhaust back to the anode inlet.
tu_ours: Recycles excess hydrogen from anode exhaust back to the anode inlet, increasing utilization range to over 10% to 30%.
tu_competitor: Uses an oxygen carrier material to transport oxygen between air and fuel, resulting in a total heat output similar to conventional combustion but with reduced NOx formation due to lower oxidation temperature (<1200Â°C)
sv_reason: The US10252243B2 reduces operational costs through the absence of gas separation steps and minimal energy penalty for CO2 capturing, while the US9257711B2 enables more efficient energy production and potential cost reduction through improved hydrogen utilization.
sv_ours: Enables more efficient energy production and potential cost reduction through improved hydrogen utilization.
sv_competitor: Reduces operational costs through the absence of gas separation steps and minimal energy penalty for CO2 capturing, estimated at 2-3% efficiency lost. Decreases NOx emissions compared to direct combustion processes.
overall_reason: The US10252243B2 patent offers a more comprehensive solution in terms of both technical uniqueness and strategic value, as it addresses cost reduction and energy efficiency issues directly related to CO2 capture processes.
